title: Behavioural Economics Cambridge Tradition 2024
text:
“We think, each of us, that we’re much more rational than we are.”
– Daniel Kahneman


“The purely economic man is indeed close to being a social moron. Economic theory has been much preoccupied with this rational fool.”
– Amartya Sen


Overview

In recent decades, economics has increasingly relied on quantitative models to understand and explore economic phenomena. Central to many of these models is the idea that agents act as rational beings and make rational choices. The emergence of behavioural economics is contextualized as a question of validity to such assumptions and a response to addressing some critical problems that irrationality raises in economic modelling. Integral to this endeavor is understanding the difference between homo-economicus (the economic man) and homo-sapiens (real humans). It is crucial to understand why economic models that assume agents behave as homo-economicus often fail in real life.
The course aims to start from the core assumptions which are often made in economics and then moves on to systematically understand why these are flawed. We then discuss some of the core themes and concepts in behavioural economics. The course aims to explain all these topics using real world examples to show why behavioural economics makes a difference. We then cover the role of behavioural economics in different areas beyond economics.


Lecture Content


Week 1. Homo-economicus OR Homo-sapiens

Day 1. Introductions
Day 2. Into the World of (ir)Rationality
Day 3. Bounds of Rationality
Day 4. Trip to the Fitzwilliam Museum
Day 5. All About Heuristics




Reading

Thaler, R. H., & Sunstein, C. R. (2021). Nudge: The Final Edition. Penguin Publishing.
Thaler, R. H. (2015). Misbehaving: The making of behavioral economics. W W Norton & Co.
Kahneman, D. (2011). Thinking, fast and slow. Farrar, Straus and Giroux.


Assessment

Students will be split into groups of 2 and will be required to research into any industry/theme of their choosing seeing how behavioural economics is used in that industry and come up with ideas about how they can concepts from behavioural economics in that industry. The students will be evaluated based on their presentations of their research in class and a short writeup that would be submitted to the instructor about their research.

title: Day 2: Into the World of (ir)Rationality
text:
Framing Effects
Tversky & Kahneman (1981)
Imagine that the U.S. is preparing for the outbreak of an unusual Asian disease, which is expected to kill 600 people. Two alternative programs to combat the disease have been proposed. Assume that the exact scientific estimate of the consequences of the programs are as follows:

Program A: 200 people will be saved
Program B: \(1/3\) probability 600 will be saved, \(2/3\) probability that no people will be saved
72 percent choose Program A and 28 percent choose Program B [N=152]

title: Day 2: Into the World of (ir)Rationality
text:
Overview

Rationality is one of the most over-used words in economics and a recurring assumption in a lot of influential models in the discipline. Assuming that agents seek to maximize their benefit appears at first glance to be intuitive and even reasonable. However a careful peeling away of the layers of what rationality means leads to the unraveling of some of these models. This lecture introduces this tenet of economics and marks the beginning of our two week journey of exploring the depths of nuance this over-used word holds.

title: Day 5: All About Heuristics
text:
Overview

We have been thinking about the bias that are created by heuristics/mental shortcuts in the decision making process. We now want to take a step back to consider why is it that we think the way we do and how does that make our decisions susceptible to being influenced. In this regard, we explore two prominent theories of behavioural economics; nudge theory and prospect theory.
The slides for this lecture can be found here: Slides


Additional Reading

Read Chapter 5 Choice Architecture from the book Nudge by Richard Thaler. You can find the chapter here:
Chapter 5: Choice Architecture

title: Day 3: Bounds of Rationality
text:
Overview

Rationality has its limits. People do not have unlimited cognitive abilities to carefully consider all options before making decisions. So people take shortcuts to simplify the decision making process. However, these shortcuts can be the source of some major bias and errors. We begin this lecture by discussing what bounded rationality is in economics and then go on to discuss about some of these important shortcuts and biases.
The slides for this lecture can be found here: Slides


Additional Reading

This is a collection of cognitive biases with some very interesting examples: https://thedecisionlab.com/biases
Read about any two that interest you.
Also watch this video about a common cognitive bias: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vKA4w2O61Xo

title: Day 5: All About Heuristics
text:
People don’t have unlimited cognitive abilities and limited attention to make decisions (bounded rationality)
To make the decision making process simpler, people rely on heuristics/mental shortcuts
Although convenient, these shortcuts can be the source of many major errors and biases
